# Duals

## Introduction

English has only a singular and a plural nouns. For any number greater than one, English uses the plural. For example,

"One house, two houses, three houses, etc."

On the other hand, Arabic uses the plural only for nouns in number three and higher. For nouns that are two in number Arabic uses the _dual_.

## Forming the dual

The dual is formed by appending [ـَانِ]{.ar} [Ani]{.trn} when the noun is in the u-state and [ـَانِ]{.ar} [Ani]{.trn} when the noun is in the a-state or i-state. Example:

| States |  a house | two houses
:-------|:-------|:-------
u-state | [بَيْتٌ]{.ar} [baytun]{.trn} | [بَيْتَانِ]{.ar} [baytAni]{.trn}
a-state | [بَيْتًا]{.ar} [baytan]{.trn}| [بَيْتَيْنِ]{.ar} [baytayni]{.trn}
i-state | [بَيْتٍ]{.ar} [baytin]{.trn} | [بَيْتَيْنِ]{.ar} [baytayni]{.trn}

Note that there are no [n]{.trn} marks for the dual, despite it being indefinite. Definite dual nouns are also formed in the same way:

| States |  the house | the two houses
:-------|:-------|:-------
u-state | [ٱَلْبَيْتُ]{.ar} [Ealbaytu]{.trn}    | [ٱَلْبَيْتَانِ]{.ar} [EalbaytAni]{.trn}
a-state | [ٱَلْبَيْتَ]{.ar} [Ealbayta]{.trn}    | [ٱَلْبَيْتَيْنِ]{.ar} [Ealbaytayni]{.trn}   
i-state | [ٱَلْبَيْتِ]{.ar} [Ealbayti]{.trn}    | [ٱَلْبَيْتَيْنِ]{.ar} [Ealbaytayni]{.trn}

If a noun ends with a looped [tAE]{.trn} [ة]{.ar}, then it is converted to a regular [tAE]{.trn} [ت]{.ar} before appending the dual suffix:

| States |  a tree | two trees
:-------|:-------|:-------
u-state | [شَجَرَةٌ]{.ar} [cajaratun]{.trn}| [شَجَرَتَانِ]{.ar} [cajaratAni]{.trn}
a-state | [شَجَرَةً]{.ar} [cajaratan]{.trn}| [شَجَرَتَيْنِ]{.ar} [cajaratayni]{.trn}
i-state | [شَجَرَةٍ]{.ar} [cajaratin]{.trn}| [شَجَرَتَيْنِ]{.ar} [cajaratayni]{.trn}

Note that if a feminine noun does not have a looped [tAE]{.trn} then it will simply be appended with [ـَانِ]{.ar} or [ـَيْنِ]{.ar}. For example, "two mothers" is [أُمَّانِ]{.ar} [EummAni]{.trn} and [أُمَّيْنِ]{.ar} [Eummayni]{.trn}.

### The dual for words ending with [اء]{.ar}

If a noun ends with an [Ealif]{.trn} followed by a [hamzah]{.trn} ([اء]{.ar}) then the [hamzah]{.trn} may get converted to a [wAw]{.trn} before adding the dual suffix. This is done based on the following rules:

1. If the [اء]{.ar} is a feminine marker then the [hamzah]{.trn} becomes a [wAw]{.trn}. For example,  
   + REMOVE (a because duals of non-descriptive nouns not yet discussed): [صَفْرَاء]{.ar} [SafrAE]{.trn} becomes [صَفْرَاوَانِ]{.ar} [SafrAwAni]{.trn} and [صَفْرَاوَيْنِ]{.ar} [SafrAwayni]{.trn}.  
   + [صَحْرَاء]{.ar} [SaHrAE]{.trn} becomes [صَحْرَاوَانِ]{.ar} [SaHrAwAni]{.trn} and [صَحْرَاوَيْنِ]{.ar} [SaHrAwayni]{.trn}.  
2. If [اء]{.ar} is not a feminine marker, then the [hamzah]{.trn} can either remain a [hamzah]{.trn}, or turn into a [و]{.ar} when adding the dual suffix, depending on the root of the word. If [hamzah]{.trn} is part of the root of the word then it will remain a [hamzah]{.trn} when adding the dual suffix. For example, the root of [خَطَّاءٌ]{.ar} [xaTTAEun]{.trn} is [خطء]{.arroot}. With the dual suffix it becomes [خَطَّاءَانِ]{.ar} [xaTTAEAni]{.trn} and [خَطَّاءَيْنِ]{.ar} [xaTTAEayni]{.trn}. On the other hand, if the [hamzah]{.trn} was originally a [و]{.ar} or [ي]{.ar} in the root, then it may either remain a [hamzah]{.trn} or turn into a [و]{.ar} when adding the dual suffix.  Examples:  
   + [دُعَاء]{.ar} [dueAE]{.trn} (root: [دعو]{.arroot}) becomes either [دُعَاءَانِ]{.ar} [dueAEAni]{.trn} and [دُعَاءَيْنِ]{.ar} [dueAEayni]{.trn} or [دُعَاوَانِ]{.ar} [dueAwAni]{.trn} and [دُعَاوَيْنِ]{.ar} [dueAwayni]{.trn}.  
   + [بِنَاء]{.ar} [binAE]{.trn} (root: [بني]{.arroot}) becomes either [بِنَاءَانِ]{.ar} [binAEAni]{.trn} and [بِنَاءَيْنِ]{.ar} [binAEayni]{.trn} or [بِنَاوَانِ]{.ar} [binAwAni]{.trn} and [بِنَاوَيْنِ]{.ar} [binAwayni]{.trn}.  

   We recommend that you retain the [hamzah]{.trn} when forming the dual, and we will specify if [و]{.ar} is preferred for a particular word.

### The dual for words ending with [ىٰ]{.ar}

If a noun ends with [ىٰ]{.ar}, then whether the [ىٰ]{.ar} is a feminine marker or not, it becomes a [yAE]{.trn} with an [a]{.trn}-mark [يَ]{.ar} when adding the dual suffix . For example,  

+ [غَضْبَىٰ]{.ar} [gaDbA]{.trn} (root: [غضب]{.arroot}) becomes [غَضْبَيَانِ]{.ar} [gaDbayAni]{.trn} and [غَضْبَيَيْنِ]{.ar} [gaDbayayni]{.trn}.
+ [ٱَلْهُدَىٰ]{.ar} [EalhudA]{.trn} (root: [هدي]{.arroot}) becomes [ٱَلْهُدَيَانِ]{.ar} [EalhudayAni]{.trn} and [ٱَلْهُدَيَيْنِ]{.ar} [Ealhudayayni]{.trn}.

## Sentences with duals

In subject-information sentences, if the subject is a dual, then the information will typically match it in being a dual. For example:

[ٱَلْمَرْأَتَانِ أُمَّانِ]{.ar}  
[EalmarEatAni EummAni]{.trn}  
"The two women are mothers."

Note that both [ٱَلْمَرْأَتَانِ]{.ar} [EalmarEatAni]{.trn} "the two women" and [أُمَّانِ]{.ar}  [EummAni]{.trn}  "two mothers" are in the u-state because, just like for sentences with singulars, the subject and information are put in the u-state.

Sometimes, however, the subject and information may not match in number because of the meaning of the sentence. For example,

[ٱَلْبِنَاءَانِ مَدْرَسَةً]{.ar}  
[EalbinAEAni madrasatan]{.trn}  
"The two buildings are a school"

## Duals of descriptive nouns

Just like common nouns, descriptive nouns can also be duals. When a descriptive noun is used to describe a dual noun, the descriptive noun will also be dual. Examples:

The two women are noble.

The two men are very angry.

The big books are heavy.

The man read two heavy books.

## Pronouns of the dual

We have learned detached pronouns, past-tense verb doer pronouns, and attached pronouns for the singular. Here we will add the corresponding pronouns for the dual.

### Detached pronouns

Pronouns for the non-participator:

1. [هُوَ]{.ar} [huwa]{.trn} "he".
2. [هِيَ]{.ar} [hiya]{.trn} "she".
6. [هُمَا]{.ar} [humA]{.trn} "they (dual masc. & fem.)".

Pronouns for the addressee:

1. [أَنْتَ]{.ar} [Eanta]{.trn} "you (sing. masc.)".
4. [أَنْتِ]{.ar} [Eanti]{.trn} "you (sing. fem.)".
7. [أَنْتُمَا]{.ar} [EantumA]{.trn} "you (dual masc. & fem.)".

Pronouns for the speaker:

1. [أَنَا]{.ar} [Eana]{.trn} "I".

Pronouns for the non-participator:

1. [◌َ]{.ar}  [a]{.trn}  "he"
2. [ـَتْ]{.ar} [at]{.trn} "she"
3. [ـَا]{.ar} [A]{.trn} "they (dual masc. & fem.)".

Pronouns for the addressee:

1. [تَ]{.ar}  [ta]{.trn} "you (sing. masc.)"
2. [تِ]{.ar}  [ti]{.trn} "you (sing. fem.)"
3. [تُمَا]{.ar} [tumA]{.trn} "you (dual masc. & fem.)".

Pronouns for the speaker:

1. [تُ]{.ar}  [tu]{.trn} "I (masc. & fem.)"
2. [نَا]{.ar} [nA]{.trn} "we (dual masc. & fem.)"

### Attached pronouns 

Pronouns for the absent:

1. [ـهُ]{.ar} [-hu]{.trn} "him".
2. [ـهَا]{.ar} [-hA]{.trn} "her".
6. [ـهُمَا]{.ar} [-humA]{.trn} "them (dual masc. & fem.)".

Pronouns for the addressee:

1. [ـكَ]{.ar} [-ka]{.trn} "you (sing. masc.)".
2. [ـكِ]{.ar} [-ki]{.trn} "you (sing. fem.)".
3. [ـكُمَا]{.ar} [-kumA]{.trn} "you (dual masc. & fem.)".

Pronouns for the speaker:

1. [نِي]{.ar} [-nI]{.trn} as a doee pronoun attached to a verb and [ـِي]{.ar} [-I]{.trn} otherwise: "me". 
2. [نَا]{.ar} [-nA]{.trn} "us (dual masc. & fem.)"

Note that just like [ـهُ]{.ar} [-hu]{.trn} "him" becomes [هِ]{.ar} [hi]{.trn}, [ـهُمَا]{.ar} [-humA]{.trn} "them (dual masc. & fem.)" too changes to [هِمَا]{.ar} [himA]{.trn} if it is preceded by the vowels [◌ِ]{.ar} [i]{.trn}, [ـِي]{.ar} [I]{.trn}, or the semi-vowel [ـَيْ]{.ar} [ay]{.trn}.
